item.title: Report E-2024100524
item.description:
Report E-2024100524

Identified by scraper @ 2024-10-23T09:14:59+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-09-21
  • City: CHARLOTTE
  • State: NC
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: At 0330 ERTS was notified by XPO Logistics of a 1gal release of UN1263 paint on the trailer. The cause was due to a forklift accident. ERTS reviewed the SDS with terminal personnel who feel comfortable cleaning the release with oil dri and proper PPE. Terminal personnel will place the waste into a 15gal metal drum in the facilities waste area.

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0

  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: 1. X-2024100971 attachment Name:image000001 (1).jpg 2. X-2024100972 Package was found on the dock with wet outer contents. Upon investigation it was found that one of the four inner containers had a loose closure, causing internal leakage. Package was placed into a hazmat bag, and then into a salvage drum.

item.title: Report E-2024100423
item.description:
Report E-2024100423

Identified by scraper @ 2024-10-21T12:23:20+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-10-08
  • City: CHARLOTTE
  • State: NC
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On October 8, 2024, one (1) 50-pound bag of UN1823 was torn in transit and released approximately three (3) pounds of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Carolina Environmental Response Team, Inc. (CERT) to remediate the impacted site. CERT personnel collected the damaged bag, impacted shrink wrap, and impacted cardboard, for disposal. Crews deployed granular absorbents to the impacted areas, and swept them in with hand tools. All impacted material was containerized in one (1) 55-gallon drum.
